revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Retta | image = Retta 2012 (cropped).jpg | alt = Retta in 2012 | caption = Retta in May 2012 | birth_name = Marietta Sangai Sirleaf | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1970|04|12}} | birth_place = [[Newark, New Jersey]], U.S. | occupation = Actress, comedian | years_active = 1998{{ndash}}present | relatives = [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]] (aunt) }} '''Marietta Sangai Sirleaf'''<ref name=NBC-ParksRec-Bio>{{cite news|title=Cast: Donna Meagle, Played by Retta|url=https://www.nbc.com/parks-and-recreation/credits/character/donna-meagle|work=[[Parks and Recreation]]|publisher=[[NBC]]}}</ref> (born April 12, 1970), better known as '''Retta''', is an American [[stand-up comedy|stand-up]] comedian and actress. She is best known for her role as [[Donna Meagle]] on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Parks and Recreation]]''. She has appeared in several films and television shows, and has performed stand-up on [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[Premium Blend]]''. She stars as Ruby Hill in NBC's ''[[Good Girls (TV series)|Good Girls]]''.<ref name=Vogue-GoodGirlsS1-2018>{{cite news|last1=Read|first1=Bridget|title=Retta Moves on From Parks and Recreation in Good Girls, But Never Say Never|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/retta-good-girls-nbc-parks-and-recreation-interview|work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|date=26 February 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==Early life== Retta was born in [[Newark, New Jersey]]. She is of Liberian descent.<ref name=WashingtonPost-Aunt-Nobel-2011>{{cite news|last1=Chaney|first1=Jen|title=What’s the connection between a Nobel Prize winner and ‘Parks and Recreation’?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/celebritology/post/whats-the-connection-between-a-nobel-prize-winner-and-parks-and-recreation/2011/10/07/gIQAjGkoSL_blog.html|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=8 October 2011}}</ref> She grew up around New Jersey, specifically in [[Edison, New Jersey|Edison]] and [[Cliffwood Beach]].<ref name=NJ-GeeksWhoDrink-JerseyRoots-2015>{{cite news|last1=Feuer|first1=Ryan|title=Comedian Retta talks Jersey roots, 'Parks and Rec' and 'Geeks Who Drink'|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2015/07/comedian_retta_talks_jersey_roots_parks_and_rec_an.html|work=[[NJ.com]]|date=16 July 2015}}</ref> In 1988, Retta graduated from [[Matawan Regional High School]] in [[Aberdeen Township, New Jersey]].<ref name=NJ-GeeksWhoDrink-JerseyRoots-2015 /><ref name=MatawanHS-Pillar-1998>{{cite book|title=Pillar 1998|date=1988|publisher=[[Matawan Regional High School]]|pages=99, 125, 144, 208, 224|url=http://www.digifind-it.com/matawan/DATA/yearbooks/1988.pdf}}</ref> In 1992, Retta graduated from [[Duke University]] in [[Durham, North Carolina]], where she was [[pre-med]] and graduated with a degree in sociology.<ref name=NJ-GeeksWhoDrink-JerseyRoots-2015 /><ref name=DukeMagazine-ParksRec-2014>{{cite news|last1=Fishbein|first1=Anne|title=Chatting With "Parks and Recreation's" Retta Sirleaf '92|url=http://dukemagazine.duke.edu/article/chatting-with-parks-and-recreations-retta-sirleaf-92|work=[[Duke Magazine]]|publisher=[[Duke University]]|date=25 September 2014|language=en}}</ref><ref name=Essence-ParksRec-7Reasons-2012>{{cite news|last1=Sangweni|first1=Yolanda|title=7 Reasons You Should Know Parks and Recreation Star, Retta|url=https://www.essence.com/2012/09/20/7-reasons-you-should-know-parks-and-recreation-star-retta|work=[[Essence (magazine)|Essence]]|date=20 September 2012|language=en}}</ref>
==Career== After graduating from Duke, Retta worked as a chemist. In her spare time, she did stand-up at Charlie Goodnights Comedy Club in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]].<ref name=DukeToday-LunchStudents-2015>{{cite news|last1=Holder|first1=Christina|title=Retta Sirleaf Returns to Duke|url=https://today.duke.edu/2015/02/retta-sirleaf-returns-duke|work=Duke Today|publisher=[[Duke University]]|date=25 February 2015|language=en|format=includes video}}</ref> Eventually she moved to [[Los Angeles]] to pursue a career in comedy.<ref name="RPN">{{Cite news|last=Azzi |first=Amy |title=Comedian took long route to comedy |publisher=University of Wisconsin-Whitewater |work=Royal Purple News |date=January 28, 2009 |url=http://media.www.royalpurplenews.com/media/storage/paper1225/news/2009/01/28/WebExtras/Comedian.Took.Long.Route.To.Comedy-3599833.shtml |accessdate=November 17, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Retta started performing stand-up comedy in 1996, although she said she did not start "earning money" until 1998, when she began touring on the college circuit. Retta said she used to get "really nauseated" before a performance, but that the feeling passed with experience.<ref name="Eells">{{Cite news|last=Eells |first=Kelly Feser |title=T-150 seats down for stand-up guys |work=Ojai Valley News |date=June 6, 2003 |url=http://www.ojaivalleynews.com/issues2003/06-June2003/06-06-03/06-06-03news5.html |accessdate=November 17, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723032720/http://www.ojaivalleynews.com/issues2003/06-June2003/06-06-03/06-06-03news5.html |archivedate=July 23, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Retta has said her stand-up material tends to be slightly embellished stories from her regular everyday life, family, and friends.<ref name="RPN" /><ref name="UIS">{{Cite news|last=Dunn |first=Valeree |title=Performer Spotlight on... Retta |work=UIS Journal |date=October 14, 2009 |url=http://www.uis.edu/journal/artsEntertainment/2009/20091014spotlightonretta.html |accessdate=November 17, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yBlCXaLK?url=http://www.uis.edu/journal/artsEntertainment/2009/20091014spotlightonretta.html |archivedate=April 24, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Retta has stated she would give up stand-up comedy for a full-time acting career if possible: "I'm not married to stand-up, just because it's a road thing. It's very lonely with all the traveling."<ref name="Echo">{{Cite news |last=Haynes |first=Robert |title=Comedian Retta brings glee to bear country |publisher=University of Central Arkansas|work=The Echo |date=November 17, 2009}}</ref>
Retta has served as the opening act for such comedians as [[Shirley Hemphill]] and Bobby Collins.<ref name="Eells" /> She has made television appearances on Bravo's ''[[Welcome to the Parker]]'', [[E!|E! Entertainment Television]]'s ''[[The Soup]]'',<ref name="UIS" /> ''[[Freddie (TV series)|Freddie]]'', ''[[Moesha]]'', ''[[It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia]]'',<ref name="Echo" /> the "Comedy Divas Showcase" segment of ''[[The Jenny Jones Show]]'',<ref>{{Cite news|last=Ory |first=Marie |title=Laughter -- the medicine of life |work=The Nicholls Worth |date=March 15, 2001 |url=http://media.www.thenichollsworth.com/media/storage/paper262/news/2001/03/15/Lagniappe/Laughter.The.Medicine.Of.Life-55719.shtml |accessdate=November 17, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Retta has performed on ''[[Premium Blend]]'', a [[Comedy Central]] show featuring up-and-coming comedians.<ref name="Eells" />
In 2009, Retta started making regular guest appearances on the [[NBC]] comedy series ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'' as [[Donna Meagle]], an employee in the Parks Department of the fictional town, [[Pawnee, Indiana]]. During a stand-up performance at the [[University of Illinois at Springfield]], Retta said the acting job on the show was stressful because it was unclear how long the show would stay on the air, due to the poor reviews it received during the [[Parks and Recreation (season 1)|first season]].<ref name="UIS" /> [[Alan Sepinwall]], a television columnist with ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'', said [[Parks and Recreation (season 2)|season 2]] episodes of ''Parks and Recreation'' afforded more personality and funnier jokes to Donna and other minor characters.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sepinwall |first=Alan |title=Parks and Recreation, "Ron and Tammy": Megan Mullally guests |work=The Star-Ledger |date=November 5, 2009 |url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/tv/index.ssf/2009/11/parks_and_recreation_ron_and_t.html |publisher=New Jersey On-Line |accessdate=November 6, 2009}}</ref> She was upgraded to a full-time regular cast member in the third season.<ref name="NJ">{{cite web |url= http://www.nj.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2015/07/comedian_retta_talks_jersey_roots_parks_and_rec_an.html|title= Comedian Retta talks Jersey roots, 'Parks and Rec' and 'Geeks Who Drink'|last1= Feuer|first1= Ryan|last2= |first2= |date= 16 July 2015|website= [[Nj.com]]|publisher= |access-date= 13 December 2015|quote=}}</ref>
Retta also hosted the [[3rd Critics' Choice Television Awards]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_bang_theory/news/1000743/|title= Awards News: Critics' Choice Nominations|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= [[CBS]]|publisher= |access-date= 13 December 2015|quote=}}</ref> In 2014, she appeared on ''[[Hollywood Game Night]]'' as a contestant along with the other celebrities [[Paget Brewster]], [[Michael Chiklis]], [[Mario Lopez]], [[Thomas Lennon (actor)|Thomas Lennon]], and [[Alyssa Milano]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ew.com/article/2014/01/15/retta-mario-lopez-hollywood-game-night|title= Retta takes on Mario Lopez in the Olympics on 'Hollywood Game Night' -- EXCLUSIVE|last1= Snetiker|first1= Marc|last2= |first2= |date= 15 January 2014 |website= [[Ew.com]]|publisher= |access-date= 13 December 2015|quote=}}</ref>
In 2015, Retta was one of the audiobook narrators for ''[[Welcome to Night Vale (novel)|Welcome to Night Vale]]'', a novel tie-in to the [[Welcome to Night Vale|eponymous podcast series]] in which she is the voice of Old Woman Josie.<ref name="NJ"/> The same year she appeared in season 2 of [[Bravo (U.S. TV network)|Bravo]]'s ''[[Girlfriends' Guide to Divorce]]''.<ref name="NJ"/>
In 2018, Retta co-starred in the [[NBC]] series, ''[[Good Girls (TV series)|Good Girls]],'' opposite [[Christina Hendricks]] and [[Mae Whitman]].<ref name=Vogue-GoodGirlsS1-2018 />
In 2018, Retta published a series of essays in a book called ''So Close to Being the Sh*T, Y'all Don't Even Know.''<ref name=SoCloseToBeing-2018>{{cite book|last1=Retta|title=So Close to Being the Sh*T, Y'all Don't Even Know|date=2018|publisher=St. Martin's Press|location=New York|isbn=978-1-250-10934-7|oclc=1001333805}}</ref>
==Personal life== Retta is the niece of the former [[President of Liberia|Liberian president]] [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]].<ref name=WashingtonPost-Aunt-Nobel-2011 />
Retta is an avid fan of the [[Los Angeles Kings]] hockey team, and presented awards at the [[NHL]] award ceremonies in [[Las Vegas]], in 2014 and 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nhl.com/kings/news/retta-how-i-became-a-hockey-fan/c-882350|title=Retta: How I Became a Hockey Fan|publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/upstream/retta-helparettaout-hockey-lesson/|title=Hey, Retta, this Tumblr is teaching you all about hockey|date=15 April 2013|publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lennyletter.com/life/a380/how-i-became-a-hockey-fan/|title=How I Became a Hockey Fan|date=11 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/sports/hockey/nhl-awards-2015-1.10577529|title=NHL Awards 2015|publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thescore.com/news/524538|title=NHL releases lineup of presenters and performers for awards show|publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref>
